messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 46 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: On the Composition of Randomized Query Complexity and Approximate Degree

Paper Abstract: Abstract For any Boolean functions f𝑓f and g𝑔g, the question whether R​(f∘g)=Θ~​(R​(f)⋅R​(g))R𝑓𝑔~Θ⋅R𝑓R𝑔\text{R}(f\circ g)=\widetilde{\Theta}(\text{R}(f)\cdot\text{R}(g)), is known as the composition question for the randomized query complexity. Similarly, the composition question for the approximate degree asks whether deg~​(f∘g)=Θ~​(deg~​(f)⋅deg~​(g))~deg𝑓𝑔~Θ⋅~deg𝑓~deg𝑔\widetilde{\text{deg}}(f\circ g)=\widetilde{\Theta}(\widetilde{\text{deg}}(f)\cdot\widetilde{\text{deg}}(g)). These questions are two of the most important and well-studied problems in the field of analysis of Boolean functions, and yet we are far from answering them satisfactorily. It is known that the measures compose if one assumes various properties of the outer function f𝑓f (or inner function g𝑔g). This paper extends the class of outer functions for which R and deg~~deg\widetilde{\text{deg}} compose. A recent landmark result (Ben-David and Blais, 2020) showed that R​(f∘g)=Ω​(noisyR​(f)⋅R​(g))R𝑓𝑔Ω⋅noisyR𝑓R𝑔\text{R}(f\circ g)=\Omega(\text{noisyR}(f)\cdot\text{R}(g)). This implies that composition holds whenever noisyR​(f)=Θ~​(R​(f))noisyR𝑓~ΘR𝑓\text{noisyR}(f)=\widetilde{\Theta}(\text{R}(f)). We show two results: 1. When R​(f)=Θ​(n)R𝑓Θ𝑛\text{R}(f)=\Theta(n), then noisyR​(f)=Θ​(R​(f))noisyR𝑓ΘR𝑓\text{noisyR}(f)=\Theta(\text{R}(f)). In other words, composition holds whenever the randomized query complexity of the outer function is full. 2. If R composes with respect to an outer function, then noisyR also composes with respect to the same outer function. On the other hand, no result of the type deg~​(f∘g)=Ω​(M​(f)⋅deg~​(g))~deg𝑓𝑔Ω⋅𝑀𝑓~deg𝑔\widetilde{\text{deg}}(f\circ g)=\Omega(M(f)\cdot\widetilde{\text{deg}}(g)) (for some non-trivial complexity measure M​(⋅)𝑀⋅M(\cdot)) was known to the best of our knowledge. We prove that deg~​(f∘g)=Ω~​(bs​(f)⋅deg~​(g)),~deg𝑓𝑔~Ω⋅bs𝑓~deg𝑔\widetilde{\text{deg}}(f\circ g)=\widetilde{\Omega}(\sqrt{\text{bs}(f)}\cdot\widetilde{\text{deg}}(g)), where bs​(f)bs𝑓\text{bs}(f) is the block sensitivity of f𝑓f. This implies that deg~~deg\widetilde{\text{deg}} composes when deg~​(f)~deg𝑓\widetilde{\text{deg}}(f) is asymptotically equal to bs​(f)bs𝑓\sqrt{\text{bs}(f)}. It is already known that both R and deg~~deg\widetilde{\text{deg}} compose when the outer function is symmetric. We also extend these results to weaker notions of symmetry with respect to the outer function.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 46 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 46"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Separations in query complexity based on pointer functions",
        "Separations in query complexity using cheat sheets",
        "Degree vs. approximate degree and quantum implications of Huang’s sensitivity theorem",
        "A composition theorem for randomized query complexity",
        "Nearly optimal separations between communication (or query) complexity and partitions",
        "Polynomial degree and lower bounds in quantum complexity: Collision and element distinctness with small range",
        "Classical lower bounds from quantum upper bounds",
        "Complexity measures and decision tree complexity: a survey",
        "A tight composition theorem for the randomized query complexity of partial functions",
        "A tight composition theorem for the randomized query complexity of partial functions: Extended abstract",
        "Randomised composition and small-bias minimax",
        "The power of many samples in query complexity",
        "When Is Amplification Necessary for Composition in Randomized Query Complexity?",
        "Randomized query complexity of sabotaged and composed functions",
        "Quantum algorithms and approximating polynomials for composed functions with shared inputs",
        "Robust polynomials and quantum algorithms",
        "Dual lower bounds for approximate degree and Markov-Bernstein inequalities",
        "Partially symmetric functions are efficiently isomorphism testable",
        "Junto-symmetric functions, hypergraph isomorphism and crunching",
        "On the sensitivity of cyclically-invariant boolean functions",
        "Separations between combinatorial measures for transitive functions",
        "The log-approximate-rank conjecture is false",
        "Block sensitivity of minterm-transitive functions",
        "An Introduction to Probability Theory and Its Applications",
        "Randomized communication versus partition number",
        "A Composition Theorem for Randomized Query Complexity via Max-Conflict Complexity",
        "Composition limits and separating examples for some Boolean function complexity measures",
        "Induced subgraphs of hypercubes and a proof of the sensitivity conjecture",
        "Quantum adversary (upper) bound",
        "Conflict complexity is lower bounded by block sensitivity",
        "Quantum query complexity of state conversion",
        "A composition theorem for decision tree complexity",
        "Crew prams and decision trees",
        "On the degree of boolean functions as real polynomials",
        "On the degree of polynomials that approximate symmetric boolean functions",
        "Reflections for quantum query algorithms, pages 560–569.",
        "Sensitivity vs. block sensitivity of Boolean functions",
        "On determinism versus unambiquous nondeterminism for decision trees",
        "Strong direct product theorems for quantum communication and query complexity",
        "Approximating the AND-OR tree",
        "The intersection of two halfspaces has high threshold degree",
        "Making polynomials robust to noise",
        "Block sensitivity of weakly symmetric functions",
        "Graph properties and circular functions: How low can quantum query complexity go?",
        "Properties and applications of boolean function composition",
        "Shrinkage of De Morgan formulae by spectral techniques"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 46 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in On the Composition of Randomized Query Complexity and Approximate Degree, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
